text: The Saint Helena hoopoe (Upupa antaios), also known as the Saint Helena giant hoopoe or giant hoopoe, is an extinct species of the hoopoe (family Upupidae), known exclusively from an incomplete subfossil skeleton. It was last seen around 1550. It was endemic to the island of Saint Helena in the South Atlantic. It was most likely flightless.Storrs L. Olson. (1975). Paleornithology of St Helena Island, south Atlantic Ocean. Smithsonian Contributions to Paleobiology 23. The first analysis of this species was given in 1963 by the British zoologist Philip Ashmole, who discovered, in the Dry Gut sediments east of Saint Helena, a left humerus which differed significantly from that of other Upupidae. The incomplete skeleton, which was found in 1975 by the palaeontologist Storrs L. Olson, consists of both coracoids and the left femur. ==References== Category:Birds of Saint Helena Island Category:Extinct flightless birds Category:Extinct birds of Atlantic islands Category:Bird extinctions since 1500 Saint Helena hoopoe Saint Helena hoopoe
title: Saint Helena hoopoe
